newsitem.title: USA: Ferrell FX Index fell 0.1 pct in July.
newsitem.headline: Ferrell FX Index fell 0.1 pct in July.

text.p: The Ferrell FX Index was off 0.1 percent in July against a 0.4 percent rise in June, according to Ferrell Capital Management.
All 35 programs in the index reported in July, and 20 of the 35 said results were positive, Ferrell said.
"The biggest market move was the dollar weakness in mid-month," said Ferrell's S. Waite Rawls. "Most discretionary traders had small positive or negative returns."
Irvington, Connecticut-based Emcor's currency management program turned in the best performance for the month, rising 6.0 percent in July, Ferrell said.
"Currency markets were vin July with the dollar falling sharply against the major European currencies," Gerhard Isele, an Emcor managing director, told Ferrell.

Kenzie Global Asset Management posted the second-largest gain for July, with its aggressive growth program rising 4.8 percent. Quantitative Financial Strategies placed third with a rise of 3.5 percent. the 115-month period from January 1987 through July 1996, the compounded annual return of the Ferrell FX Index is 17.7 percent, according to Ferrell.
The index is intended to be a benchmark for multi-advisor currency portfolios.
